snippet: Legal practitioners and Supreme Court justices say it is the rare oral argument that wins or loses a case.
abstract: News analysis questions the usefulness of analyzing the strength of oral arguments made before the Supreme Court, in light of the criticism that Solicitor General Donald B Verrilli Jr has received for his arguments in several cases; observes that oral arguments rarely win or lose cases. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Washington SUPREME COURT advocacy is not usually a spectator sport, so it may have surprised Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. when the reviews of his defense of President Obama's health care law started to roll in.

headline.main: Are Oral Arguments Worth Arguing About?
